did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Educational Interests, Series G

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records are arranged by subject matter in 27 series. Most of these series are wholly or partially open for research. The series are:

A John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; C Business Interests; D Civic Interests; E Cultural Interests; F Economic Reform Interests; G Educational Interests; H Friends and Services; I Homes; J Housing Interests; K Medical Interests; L Real Estate; M Maps and Memorabilia; N Religious Interests; O Rockefeller Boards; P Welfare - General Files; Q World Affairs; R Welfare - Youth Files; S Documents; T Public Relations; U Public Land Law Review Commission; V Greenrock; W Properties; X Costume Collection; Y Media; Z John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal; AA Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; AC Abby Rockefeller Mauz√©

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The central figure in the creation and operation of the Standard Oil Company during its rise to the top of the petroleum industry, John D. Rockefeller (JDR) established for the family a leading role in business and philanthropy. From the days of his earliest employment, Rockefeller, a devout Baptist, was generous in his giving to worthy causes, especially those of a religious nature. During the 1890s he developed an orderly system of philanthropic giving through an office staff that included his close advisor, Frederick T. Gates (1853-1929) and his son, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960). With the advise of these and other associates, Rockefeller established the University of Chicago, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now The Rockefeller University), the Rockefeller Foundation, and other philanthropic organizations working nationally and internationally in the fields of education, religion, and health. Rockefeller's total donations to philanthropic endeavors are estimated to have been $540 million.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (JDR Jr.) joined his father's office on October 1, 1897. He oversaw the expansion and diversification of the philanthropic work begun by his father. During his lifetime, the younger Rockefeller gave more than $537 million to educational, religious, cultural, medical, and other charitable projects.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1874-1948), passed the Rockefeller philanthropic impulse on to their children. John D. 3rd (1906-1978), Nelson A. (1908-1979), Laurance S. (1910-2004), Winthrop (1912-1973), and David (1915-) further expanded and diversified Rockefeller influence and interests, establishing their own philanthropic organizations, most notably the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1940), and becoming more active politically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) materials document the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons, John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David, into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office.

This material contains correspondence, reports, pamphlets, memoranda, deeds, maps, contracts, reports, minutes, charters, certificates of incorporation, clippings, diaries, notebooks, calendars, and memorabilia.
There is a microfilm card index of personal and institutional names.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The files found in this series include correspondence by members of the Rockefeller family and their representatives and the officials of various institutions. Most of the material is unsolicited requests for aid. The material on institutions in which the family took an active interest, such as the International Houses, includes analysis, reports, general correspondence, contributions, and administration.

The Schools section and the Colleges section both include information on the schools attended by the Rockefeller brothers and cousins. There is a significant amount of information about the University of Chicago. The Foreign Colleges section includes a substantial amount of information on the University of Paris.

The family member who appears most prominently in this series is John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Other family members are John D. Rockefeller, Sr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and Winthrop Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences
Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller contributes to concert building in Brooklyn; declines to endow Academy. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributes $250,000 to Brooklyn Botanical Gardens. David Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller 3rd life members. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, David Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Carnegie Boards - David Rockefeller Interests

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: David Rockefeller elected to board of trustees of Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in 1947. Treasurer in 1949. Hiss resignation, search for new President. Programs; history of fund. Congressional investigations. Proposed programs, David Rockefeller comments and suggestions. 1961 gift to scholarship fund. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, Alger Hiss, John Foster Dulles, James T. Shotwell.

did.unittitle: Chinese Mass Education Movement
Chinese Mass Education Movement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Using simplified Chinese alphabet, James Yen tried to broaden education in China. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contribution, 1930. Discussion of value of movement; support by Rockefeller Foundation. Wartime fund raising efforts by Yen; deteriorating conditions in China. Efforts to extend Yen's techniques into Latin America.

did.unittitle: George Junior Republic
George Junior Republic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Institution for delinquent boys organized as a self-governing community. John D. Rockefeller contributed jail and court-house building, and towards current expenses. Final meeting to set up Republic held in John D. Rockefeller's home, 1898. 1909 Gift to expand physical plant. Almost constant financial and managerial problems from 1916 on; requests for endowments refused. Laurance S. Rockefeller's 1950 contribution. No further family contributions. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Willard S. Richardson, V. E. Macy.

did.unittitle: International House, New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Harry Edmonds founds Cosmopolitan Club in 1911; appealed to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for financial aid. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. buys property near Columbia University for International House; gave $1,000,000 for building dormitory and social center for foreign students, 1921. Building completed, 1924. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Address, November 18, 1923. Religious policy of House, activities, studies; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s speeches and small gifts. Fund-raising program. Correspondents include Harry Edmonds, John L. Mott, Arthur Jones, David Rockefeller, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: International House - John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s Contributions to International House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. increased initial pledge of $1,000,000 to $1,800,00 to provide ample plant for long-range plan. Pledges made through Raymond B. Fosdick; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. wanted an ideal building, and pledged a further $200,000 in confidence to Raymond B. Fosdick. Payment of recording fees, interest on mortgage, change of pledge to securities in 1922. Total initial gift value over $2,500,000. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Raymond B. Fosdick, F. Osborn, Cleveland E. Dodge.

did.unittitle: International House - Correspondence - Harry Edmonds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edmonds finds need for Houses in Philadelphia, Boston, Chicago, Berkeley. Raymond B. Fosdick decides Edmonds ill-equipped to handle expansion. (1924-1927) Edmonds' efforts to reassociate with International House after his resignation. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s lack of confidence because of his personal actions. Personal problems. Edmonds' ambitious plans for extension of House idea; manuscript history of House. (1935-1961) Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Raymond B. Fosdick, H. Edmonds.

International House, Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charles O. Heydt and Raymond B. Fosdick trustees for property on Charles River Esplanade. Management of property, treatment of tenants; National Recovery Act (NRA) code. Decision made not to build House in Boston. Attempts to sell property. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Boston Real Estate agents.

did.unittitle: International House, Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charles O. Heydt and Raymond B. Fosdick trustees for property on Charles River Esplanade. Management of property, treatment of tenants; National Recovery Act (NRA) code. Decision made not to build House in Boston. Attempts to sell property. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Boston Real Estate agents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Trustees held property for John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: International House, Boston - Sale of Land to Massachusetts Institute of Technology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many unsuccessful attempts to sell property through Boston brokers. In 1942 property sold to Massachusetts Institute of Technology at great loss; savings realized in tax structure. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: International House - International Students Association of Greater Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines involvement in Association on the basis that his contributions to International House fulfilled his obligation in that direction. John D. Rockefeller 3rd gives $20,000, 1953. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Edgar B. Young, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, L. M. Mead, Jerome D. Greene.

did.unittitle: International House Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An association coordinating Houses in Chicago, New York, and Berkeley. Selection of an executive; incorporation and planning; temporary director. Leon de Rosen appointed director. Organizational politics. David Rockefeller active in program to increase educational activity of International Houses; his speech, November 11, 1949. Contributions by David Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller. de Rosen's resignation. Chapters of Association in other countries. 1953, David Rockefeller reduces his support of Association. Herrick Young resigns as director; changes in Association, 1958. International Conference in Paris, 1961; David Rockefeller attended. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, John Mott, R. Sproul, Leon de Rosen, Herrick Young.

Fringe Benefits Organizations - United Parents Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Schools - Foreign Service Educational Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on Foundation sponsoring School of Advanced International Studies; C. Herter's report on foreign service training. School attacked for pro-Arab policies. Nelson A. Rockefeller's nonrecurring contributions. Correspondents include Christian Herter, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Schools - Palmer Memorial Institute, North Carolina

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Private school for Negroes; requests aid but John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined on ground that General Education Board recommends that school merge with public school system (whites unwilling to pay taxes for public Negro schools while Northerners support private Negro education). Difficulties in merger with public school system. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines further appeals; Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's annual contributions, 1930-1948. Correspondents include Dr. Wallace Buttrick, Dr. Charlotte Brown, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Schools - Mooseheart

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Order runs orphanage school at Mooseheart. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declination of invitation to become Life Member of Loyal Order of Moose. Order appeals for contributions for school; General Education Board reports; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s nonrecurring anonymous contribution, 1924; further appeals declined. Correspondents include James J. Davis, Thomas B. Appleget, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., T. Arnett.

did.unittitle: Schools - Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Outgrowth of Goethe Bicentennial Foundation (Robert Hutchins, chairman) which received contributions from Rockefeller Foundation and Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Declination of requests and invitations; David Rockefeller's gift providing scholarship to Aspen for Wanda Maxmillian. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, Dana S. Creel, Mrs. C. D. Barnes, Walter A. Paepke.

scopecontent.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and John D. Rockefeller 3rd give $200,000 towards cost of new music building. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Schools - Rabun Gap-Nacoochee School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rabun Gap a unique farm school for poor mountain whites; received contributions from John D. Rockefeller, Jr., 1920, 1924; his 1925 conditional pledge cancelled and replaced with larger pledge in 1927 aiding merger of Rabun Gap and Nacoochee schools. Religious cooperation problem after merger. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s 1937 contribution to endowment fund, 1939 contribution to retirement fund for Ritchies. Some printed material describing school. Correspondents include A. J. Ritchie, Rev. J. H. Hargreaves, Willard S. Richardson, Thomas B. Appleget.

did.unittitle: Schools - Rabun Gap-Nacoochee School - Contributions
Schools - Riverdale Country School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines to participate in school's 1937 expansion program. Nelson A. Rockefeller's $1,000 contribution to 1945 property purchase (Rodman Rockefeller attended for a year). Declination of further appeals to develop a "world" school with an international student body. Correspondents include Charles Keppell, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Willard S. Richardson, F. S. Hackett.

did.unittitle: Schools - Rhode Island School of Design

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lucy Truman Aldrich and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller interested. 1951-1956 David Rockefeller and Nelson A. Rockefeller contributions to Abby Aldrich Rockefeller memorial rooms in school's art museum. Later appeals declined. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, Dana S. Creel, William Edwards.

did.unittitle: Schools - Scarborough School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller 3rd's interest in school's "Work Program," his 1946 and 1949 nonrecurring contributions. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's son attended school; John D. Rockefeller 3rd's advice on financing independent schools. David Rockefeller's nonrecurring anonymous contribution, 1960; John D. Rockefeller 3rd 1960 contribution. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Charles Tillinghast, Jonathan Bingham, Mrs. F. Vanderlip.

did.unittitle: Schools - School of Design in Chicago

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Schools - Salem School - Kurt Hahn Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Hahn's attempt to "rescue" European youth, especially post-war German students, through establishment of special schools in Germany and Great Britain which would develop the "service motive." John D. Rockefeller 3rd and David Rockefeller interested (John D. Rockefeller 3rd gifts, 1950 and 1952); Rockefeller Foundation grant for German exchange students; support of United States High Commissioner for Germany, McCloy. Printed materials on Hahn Project, Gordonstown School, and articles and reports by Hahn. Declinations of later appeals. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Arthur W. Packard, Kurt Hahn, John McCloy, Robert Bates, Christian Herter.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Bowdoin College

scopecontent.p: Family declined to contribute. General Education Board grant. David Rockefeller receives honorary degree, 1958; David Rockefeller's involvement in Oakes property project, his 1960 contribution to Bowdoin. Coles declined gift for "conscience" reasons - much puzzlement and diplomacy followed. David Rockefeller repledged, accepted in 1962. Correspondents include Robert C. Bates, James S. Coles, Bela W. Norton, David Rockefeller, Thomas M. Debevoise, Dana S. Creel.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Brown University - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller declines 1911 request for $1,000,000. Trevor Arnett 1919 study of Brown finances. Small gifts for special purposes. Class reunions, alumni news. Plans for school's future; changes in administration; appeals for contributions. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. portrait by Salisbury given to Brown; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. given Brown award, 1956. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. death. Correspondents include Thomas B. Appleget, Willard S. Richardson, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur Allen, W. P. Faunce, C. A. Barbour, H. Wriston, B. C. Keeney.

scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $500 in 1934 and 1935 toward photostating of Lincoln material in other collections for Brown collection. In 1937 he gave $1,000 as a final gift for this purpose. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., H. B. Van Hoesen.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Brown University - Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. served on board of Graduate Advisory Committee. Made small, irregular contributions. Much discussion of Y General Secretaries at Brown. Coordination of Y and Brown Union activities. Willard S. Richardson took over John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s direct interest in Y. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made small contributions to budget. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., W. H. Faunce, Willard S. Richardson, G. Colby.

did.unittitle: Colleges - College of William and Mary - Endowment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal to make college a privately endowed school; J. S. Bryan elected president in 1934 to engineer shift from state control to private endowment. Discussion of relations between college and Rockefeller, Inc.: would the college take over the restoration or the restoration take over the college? Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Harry F. Byrd, John S. Bryan, Kenneth Chorley.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Columbia University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller contributes $1,000 toward commercial course, and toward interest payments, 1901-1902. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1919 contribution toward War Deficit; aid to needy student. Laurance S. Rockefeller attends ceremonies for installation of Dwight D. Eisenhower, 1948. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s recommendation of J. Campbell for Treasurer. David Rockefeller and Margaret (Peggy) McGrath Rockefeller sponsors for Theater Benefit, 1950. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines honorary degree, 1953, and award for public health service. David Rockefeller declines trusteeship 1953; David Rockefeller on sponsoring committee for 1956 Mozart Festival. Relation of Columbia Arts Project to Lincoln Center. Declinations of various appeals for contributions to the many "little offspring of Columbia." 1954 "Columbia Heritage" article on Rockefeller and Harkness philanthropy re Columbia. Correspondents include M. W. Butler, Seth Low, Mr. and Mrs. Eisenhower, Grayson Kirk, Davidson Taylor, Harry Carman, Raymond B. Fosdick, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Columbia University - Barnard College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller conditional gift of $25,000 in 1896; $10,000 in 1898. $250,000 endowment pledge, 1901. John D. Rockefeller a member of first board of trustees, 1889. Rockefeller 3rd, George Rogers, Miss V. C. Gildersleave.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Columbia University - East Asian Institute

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Institute, backed by John D. Rockefeller 3rd, establishes exchange program of Japanese and American intellectuals. Correspondence re program, minutes of committee meetings, lists of intellectuals considered for export. Reports on Fusae Ichikawa's and Dr. Yoshishage Abe's trips to United States; reports by Charles Cole, Fathers D'Arcy and Ford, Harry Carman, and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt on their trips to Japan. Report on Pilot Project for Japanese-American Cultural Relations. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Eleanor Roosevelt, Charles Cole, Sir George Sanson, Harry J. Carman, Saxton E. Bradford, Shigeharu Matsumoto, Yasaka Takagi, D. H. McLean.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Hartford Seminary Foundation / Hartford Theological Seminary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Foundation to train Bible teachers, not ministers. Letter by Frederick T. Gates on need to educate the common man; Frederick T. Gates urges personal donation to liberal colleges. Willard S. Richardson and Raymond B. Fosdick disagree widely on propriety of gift to Foundation in 1924. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. ultimately decided to give $250,000. Offered $300,000 conditionally in 1929 - only $23,000 paid. Requests declined after 1939. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, Raymond B. Fosdick, Frederick T. Gates. Dr. E. K. Mitchell.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Harvard University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller's $1,000,000 conditional gift to Harvard Medical School, 1902; discussion of school's role in medical research; printed copy of Starr J. Murphy's report. 1918 appeal for aid to School of Education referred to General Education Board. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's projects for Japanese-American intellectuals exchange program and Distinguished Service Fellowship program, 1951-1952; Conant not interested, so John D. Rockefeller 3rd took them to Columbia and Princeton. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines honorary degree, 1957. The Program for Harvard College fund campaign - contributions by John D. Rockefeller 3rd (at David Rockefeller's request), $50,000; Nelson A. Rockefeller, $51,000; David Rockefeller, $1,500,000. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines John D. Rockefeller 3rd's 1959 recommendation of King of Thailand for honorary degree. Nelson A. Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller 3rd's parents contributions. Correspondents include E. O. Reischauer, Nathan Pusey, R. Keith Kane, Sebastian S. Kresge, Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Harvard University - State Department Training Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller 3rd interested in setting up program at Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration in conjunction with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) for special training of foreign service information personnel. McLean's draft outlines and memos on his negotiations with State Department and University personnel. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's contribution covering program's cost. Then State Department backed out for budgetary reasons, and project and grant dropped. Correspondents include D. H. McLean, Robert Freeman, Edward Mason, Paul Herzog, Theodore G. Streibert, John Foster Dulles, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Many other small contributions to special projects. 1955-1957 gift of $1,000,000 for Harvard College; $500,000 gift to endow Abby Aldrich Rockefeller professorship in Oriental Art, 1957. Gift of two portraits, 1959; support for student magazine of political opinions. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, Richard Dana, James B. Conant.

Colleges - Johns Hopkins University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for aid arose after city fire wiped out a large part of the University's property holdings held by the Hospital of the University. John D. Rockefeller gave $500,000 to help situation and add to endowment. Later gifts to Medical Department. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s praise of Dr. Welch, 1941 letter. Laurance S. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. decline various invitations and appeals. Re the painting of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in Shriver Memorial. Dr. Alan Cherney uses family materials for his book on University Hospital and Medical School. Correspondents include William Welch, Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, Dr. Milton Eisenhower, Laurance S. Rockefeller, David Rockefeller.

Richardson's wife's association with college. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, Starr J. Murphy.

did.unittitle: Colleges - New York University - Bellevue Medical Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York City decides to rebuild Bellevue Hospital. New York University cooperating by building large medical center in conjunction with hospital. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributes $500,000 initially. John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller and Nelson A. Rockefeller on committee for Center. Rockefeller Brothers Fund contributes $25,000. Winthrop Rockefeller Chairman of Board of Trustees of Medical Center; contributes $1,000,000. Reports on progress of campaign; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. appeals to Alta Prentice to contribute. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s gift of $1,000,000, 1946-1949. Declinations of later invitations and appeals by John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and David Rockefeller; Winthrop Rockefeller's speech to College of Medicine Alumni, 1950; receives Benefactors Award, 1952. Rockefeller Brothers Fund contribution, 1961. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Arthur Jones, Dr. Howard Rusk.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Princeton-in-Asia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly Princeton-Yenching Foundation. Collection agency in United States for support of Yenching University in China. John D. Rockefeller 3rd and Laurance S. Rockefeller made annual nominal contributions. Stopped contributing when Reds took over Peking and program switched to providing scholarship aid for Chinese students in America. Name changed, 1955; John D. Rockefeller 3rd small gift. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Rockefeller 3rd's memorial on Karl Compton. Re Takashi Kobayashi, 1956. Correspondence re honorary degrees to foreign statesmen; screening committee for new President; invitation to Alger Hiss to speak at the University; various other University matters involving Trustees. Photo of Princetonian staff, including John D. Rockefeller 3rd. By-Laws, 1955; "Facts About Princeton," 1961. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Harold W. Dodds, Robert Goheen, Chester Bowles, Christian Herter.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Princeton University - John D. Rockefeller 3rd - Public Service Awards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Setting up the program for special training of civilian government employees; selection of winners. Problems of awardees and of getting active support from Dulles and President Eisenhower. Attempts to get congressional legislation creating this type of training program. Photos of John F. Kennedy, Robert Goheen, and John D. Rockefeller 3rd. 1956 evaluation of program; 1960 changes in program. 1961 speeches by Dean Rusk and John D. Rockefeller 3rd at Awards Luncheon. Correspondents include James Mitchell, Harry S. Truman, Arthur S. Flemming, Sam Rayburn, Olin Johnson, C. Douglas Dillon, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Smith College, Northampton, Massachusetts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hope Aldrich's contributions, 1960-1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller $100,000 conditional gift for endowment and buildings, 1901. No giving afterward until John D. Rockefeller 3rd's anonymous contribution in 1947. Margaret Sanger given honorary degree on John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s recommendation, 1949. Large 1950 contribution by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. as tribute to Mrs. Morrow. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's contributions, 1956-1959, as father of Smith student. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, Mrs. Amanda Kane.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller purchases property for college through American Baptist Home Mission Society. Plans for expansion; appeals for aid. Racial conditions in Atlanta. Naming of buildings; college status in 1924. Invitations; selection of president; activities of Spelman graduates. Tributes to Rockefellers. Gift of Spelman portraits by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Mary French Rockefeller a trustee; Winthrop Rockefeller address at 1959 commencement. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Mary French Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, Dana S. Creel, H. G. Morehouse, Florence M. Read.

Day was such a defender of Standard Oil Company; later requests declined. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, John D. Archibald, Frederick T. Gates.

scopecontent.p: Frederick T. Gates and Starr J. Murphy urge contribution in 1912; John D. Rockefeller gives $250,000. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gives $1,000,000 in 1924, plus small gift towards chair in theological research. Further gifts by John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, and John D. Rockefeller 3rd. Invitations. Contributions towards Niebuhr chair. Activities of seminary. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Willard S. Richardson, Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Yorke Allen.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - Early History - Frederick T. Gates File

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1887 Augustus H. Strong urged founding of Baptist University in New York. T. W. Goodspeed describes sickly college in Chicago, urges reorganization, 1886. W. R. Harper concurs. Harper's study of Old Testament. Frederick T. Gates joines American Baptist Education Society in May 1888, favors Chicago site. Harper insists on large endowment before becoming president. Frederick T. Gates urges Harper to reduce outside activity; controls University finances. Faculty problems; administration. Starr J. Murphy's 1904 inspection trip. W. R. Harper's operation and death. Comments on "tainted money." Correspondents include A. H. Strong, T. W. Goodspeed, W. R. Harper, Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

Colleges - University of Chicago - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Academic freedom, financial affairs, end of large gifts by John D. Rockefeller. Gifts from other sources, requests for aid from staff members. General conditions. Max Mason becomes President. Special small gifts. R. M. Hutchins becomes President. Tributes to Rockefeller. Proposed merger with Northwestern. John D. Rockefeller's portrait. University activities, invitations. General Education Board, Rockefeller Foundation and family relation to University. Urban renewal. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Frederick T. Gates, H. P. Judson, E. D. Burton, Willard S. Richardson, Max Mason, R. M. Hutchins, Raymond B. Fosdick, C. Girkey, Lawrence Kimpton, Harold Dobbs.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - American Institute of Sacred Literature

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded by W. R. Harper, 1891; incorporated into University of Chicago, 1905. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. financed printing and distribution of evangelical pamphlets. Annual grants. John D. Rockefeller bought stock in company which published Dr. Harper's books. Company was liquidated but name continued as part of University extension work. Harper wants Institute made a formal part of University work, 1903. Arranged in 1905. Frederick T. Gates refused to give it any money. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, W. R. Harper.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - American Institute of Sacred Literature

Harper wants Institute made a formal part of University work, 1903. Arranged in 1905. Frederick T. Gates refused to give it any money. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, W. R. Harper.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - Events - Anniversaries and By-Laws, etc. - Incorporation and By-Laws
Colleges - University of Chicago - Events - re: Denominational Question and Charter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: University ineligible for Carnegie pension funds because of Baptist control incorporated in by-laws and recognized by Rockefeller pledges. 1909, Rockefeller pledges modified to allow change if denomination so desired. Attempts to change charter, 1921-1923; succeeded in 1923. Northern Baptist Convention changed by-laws. John D. Rockefeller, in 1928, removed all conditions re his gifts.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - Carillon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. offers to give carillon as memorial to his mother. Consultation with experts; specifications and estimates; inscription; tariff problem. 1932 dedication, letters of congratulation. Correspondence with carillonneur, James Lawson. Memorial concert for John D. Rockefeller, Jr., 1960. Correspondents include F. C. Mayer, H. H. Swift, C. F. Johnston, James Lawson, Robert W. Gumbel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - Chapel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for chapel as memorial to Laura Spelman Rockefeller. John D. Rockefeller contributed $1,500,000 out of 1910 gift toward chapel. Location of chapel; dedication, 1929. Chapel originally called University chapel; changed in 1937 to Rockefeller Memorial Chapel. Laurance S. Rockefeller picture in carillon room. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Frederick T. Gates, T. C. Chamberlin, H. P. Judson.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - 1955 Campaign

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Campaign to be the beginning of long-term fund-raising movement. Maps for proposed expansion and renewal projects. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declines to be the big contributor - makes gift through David Rockefeller as anonymous donor. Harold Swift's 1955 address; Dana S. Creel and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. re ultimate survival of University. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., L. Kimpton.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - Oriental Investigation Fund - Dr. Ernest D. Burton FC #12 - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Excellent Frederick T. Gates letter, 1907, on future of work in China; education how and why. Frederick T. Gates urges Burton be sent to investigate China conditions. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. underwrote part of Burton's trip to Orient. Excellent personal letters describing conditions in Far East. Good policy letters by Frederick T. Gates. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Ernest D. Burton, E. Judson.

did.unittitle: Colleges - University of Chicago - David Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests for aid; David Rockefeller's election to Board of Trustees; David Rockefeller comments on Communism at University. Thomas M. Debevoise possibly worried about it, but regains his faith. Declinations; David Rockefeller policy of not serving as fund-raising trustee. Summarized reports; appointment to ad hoc neighboring committee, 1953. Materials for report on Institutional Philosophies - Harvard and University of Chicago. Noted for David Rockefeller's introduction of Kimpton, 1953, and Convocation Speech, 1954. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, Thomas M. Debevoise, Edward Ryerson, Harold Swift

did.unittitle: Colleges - Vanderbilt University - School of Religion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that John D. Rockefeller, Jr. assist in establishing non-denominational seminary at Vanderbilt. Willard S. Richardson very much in favor of it. General Education Board contribution. Later request in 1924; Willard S. Richardson checked with Frederick T. Gates who was strongly opposed. Reports on progress made with $25,000 for five years given by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in 1926. Interesting commentary on religious giving by Frederick T. Gates, who did not favor John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s "modernist" stand when he took it, but once it was taken stood behind him on it. Reluctance based on political reasons. 1931 Pledge of $25,000 for five years; $500,000 conditional pledge toward endowment. 1954 Sealantic gift. Declinations of various invitations, appeals, and proposed honors. Correspondents include J. H. Kirkland, O. E. Brown, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson, Dr. Harvie Branscomb.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Vassar College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller and Frederick T. Gates trustees, 1896-1905. John D. Rockefeller contributed toward building, aid to students, books. Problems of a women's college. 1904 gift to endowment. Andrew Carnegie on extravagance in Vassar's buildings. Comparisons of Bryn Mawr and Vassar. Remodeling Rockefeller Hall; fire in 1918. Salary increases, 1922. Contributions by special projects by John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, J. M. Taylor.

did.unittitle: Colleges - Wellesley College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Poor financial condition, 1899-1900; 1900 controversy over accepting "tainted money" as faculty members urged against accepting Rockefeller gift. Professor Jenks of Cornell arbitrated, and Wellesley took the money. Grant for heating plant. Construction of heating system very poor; reconstruction necessary. John D. Rockefeller gave further assistance. Contributions ended with creation of General Education Board. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contribution to rebuild Stone Hall after fire. Contributions by Nelson A. Rockefeller and Laurance S. Rockefeller. Correspondents include Caroline Hoyard, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates.

Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, A. S. Phelps, Winthrop Rockefeller.

Foreign Colleges - Lingnan University - Pledge and Payments - May 8, 1925 Pledge, Amended December 2, 1926

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Until 1926, the university was known as Canton Christian College. John D. Rockefeller conditional pledge of up to $500,000 to aid in expansion and strengthening of school, 1925. College borrowed $100,000 in anticipation; events in China ruined campaign for funds. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. canceled note for $100,000 and returned $8,000 in interest. By modifying original pledge John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s contribution increased to full $500,000. No later requests. Correspondents include B. Ruml, Arthur Woods, R. P. Guesee, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Fred Osborne.

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - United Board for Christian Colleges in China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Board to help thirteen colleges. 1946 Rockefeller Foundation gift to fund reconstruction of colleges. Many very interesting accounts of Communist takeover in China, up until nationalization of the colleges. Then United Board for Christian Colleges in China gave up and turned to efforts in Formosa and Hong Kong. 1957 Report. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined to contribute, 1959. Correspondents include Henry Luce, Henry P. Van Dusen, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - University of Paris (Cit√©)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan to build living accommodations for American students at University; similar residences built by other countries. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributed $2,000,000 in 1928; increased gift to $3,500,000. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. assumes full responsibility for building center; changes architects; followed construction, landscaping closely. Analysis of budget and operations. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. built a social center rather than a dormitory. Nelson A. Rockefeller very active in planning. Dissatisfaction with House administration. The War, repair of damage, sending of food. Miss Melson sent to Paris. David Rockefeller's interest. Printed materials. Correspondents include N. Butler, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Raymond B. Fosdick, W. Bosworth, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Phillip Keebler, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Harry Edmonds, David Rockefeller, John L. Mott, A. Desclos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pledges on June 7, 1928, April 30, 1930, January 14, 1931, and February 1935. Originally $2,000,000; raised to $3,600,000; small additional gifts.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous payments, purchase of francs.

scopecontent.p: Senator sent Christmas gift to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Friendly relations between Senator and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. No problems of Cit√© in this material.

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - West China Union University, Chengtu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of college. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interested, but declined appeal. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., James Wood, Ernest D. Burton.

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - Women's Christian Colleges in the Orient

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeated appeals from Women's Medical College at Vellore, India; all declined. Appeals to General Education Board and Rockefeller Foundation also failed. Correspondents include Thomas B. Appleget, Willard S. Richardson, Arthur W. Packard, Hilda L. Olson, Ida Scudder, Mrs. Henry Peabody.

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - Women's Christian Colleges in the Orient

did.unittitle: Foreign Colleges - Yenching University, Peking, China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: H. E. Fosdick urges John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to aid Christian religious training in Chinese schools. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. prefers to stay with medical training, but agrees to contribute $50,000 anonymously to Peking University, 1922. Declines further appeals. Small 1934 contribution. Reports on school and China during war and Revolution. Correspondents include Henry W. Luce, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., H. E. Fosdick.
